title: Natsuko Hara
text:
is a former <a href="Japan">Japan</a>ese <a href="Association%20football">football</a> player. She played for <a href="Japan%20women%27s%20national%20football%20team">Japan national team</a>.
Club career.
Hara was born in <a href="Ome%2C%20Tokyo">Ome</a> on March 1, 1989. She was promoted to <a href="Nippon%20TV%20Beleza">Nippon TV Beleza</a> from youth team in 2006. Especially since 2009, she played in many games as a successor of <a href="Japan%20women%27s%20national%20football%20team">Japan national team</a> player <a href="Homare%20Sawa">Homare Sawa</a> moved to United States. She played until 2015. In 10 seasons, she played 149 matches in <a href="L.League">L.League</a> and she was selected Best Eleven in <a href="2015%20L.League">2015</a>.
National team career.
In April 2005, when Hara was 16 years old, she was selected <a href="Japan%20women%27s%20national%20under-17%20football%20team">Japan U-17 national team</a> for <a href="2005%20AFC%20U-17%20Women%27s%20Championship">2005 AFC U-17 Championship</a>. At the tournament, she played as captain and she became top scorer with 12 goals. She
was named <a href="AFC%20Annual%20Awards%23Women%27s%20Footballer%20of%20the%20Year">Asian Footballer of the Year</a>. In November 2008, Natsuko Hara was selected for the <a href="Japan%20women%27s%20national%20under-20%20football%20team">Japan U-20 national team</a> for the <a href="2008%20FIFA%20U-20%20Women%27s%20World%20Cup">2008 U-20 World Cup</a>. On January 13, 2010, she played for the <a href="Japan%20women%27s%20national%20football%20team">Japan national team</a> for the first time against <a href="Denmark%20women%27s%20national%20football%20team">Denmark</a>. She played two games for Japan in 2010.
